verses.text: Now King Solomon loved many foreign women, along with the daughter of Pharaoh: Moabite, Ammonite, Edomite, Sidonian, and Hittite women,
verses.comment: Retains the list of people groups Solomon married into as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: from the nations concerning which the LORD had told the people of Israel, ‘You shall not associate with them, neither shall they associate with you, for they will surely turn your heart after their gods.’ Solomon clung to these in love.
verses.comment: The prohibition and warning from God are directly stated for clarity.

verses.text: He had seven hundred wives, princesses, and three hundred concubines. And his wives turned his heart away.
verses.comment: The numbers and roles are preserved as in original.

verses.text: For when Solomon was old, his wives turned his heart after other gods, and his heart was not wholly true to the LORD his God, as was the heart of David his father.
verses.comment: The phrase 'not wholly true' follows standard idiom for 'not perfect' in Hebrew.

verses.text: For Solomon went after Ashtoreth the goddess of the Sidonians, and after Milcom the abomination of the Ammonites.
verses.comment: 'Milcom' maintained rather than 'Molech'—per Hebrew manuscripts.

verses.text: So Solomon did what was evil in the sight of the LORD and did not fully follow the LORD, as David his father had done.
verses.comment: Standard wording kept for 'did what was evil in the sight of the LORD.'

verses.text: Then Solomon built a high place for Chemosh, the abomination of Moab, on the mountain east of Jerusalem, and for Molech, the abomination of the Ammonites.
verses.comment: 'The mountain east of Jerusalem' = the Mount of Olives by tradition.

verses.text: So he did for all his foreign wives, who made offerings and sacrificed to their gods.
verses.comment: States the extent to which Solomon permitted idolatry.

verses.text: And the LORD became angry with Solomon, because his heart had turned away from the LORD, the God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice
verses.comment: Reference to God's previous appearance to Solomon is retained.

verses.text: and had commanded him about this thing, that he should not go after other gods. But he did not obey what the LORD commanded.
verses.comment: Follows Hebrew syntax closely.

verses.text: Therefore the LORD said to Solomon, 'Since this has been done by you, and you have not kept my covenant and my statutes that I commanded you, I will surely tear the kingdom from you and give it to your servant.
verses.comment: 'Tear the kingdom' is a legal phrase for division of rule.

verses.text: Yet for the sake of David your father, I will not do it in your days, but I will tear it out of the hand of your son.
verses.comment: Reference to God's faithfulness to David’s line.

verses.text: However, I will not tear away the entire kingdom. I will give one tribe to your son, for the sake of David my servant and for the sake of Jerusalem, which I have chosen.
verses.comment: One tribe refers to Judah (with Benjamin).

verses.text: And the LORD raised up an adversary against Solomon, Hadad the Edomite. He was of the royal family in Edom.
verses.comment: Adversary = 'satan' in Hebrew (not the devil, but an opponent).

verses.text: For when David was in Edom, and Joab the commander of the army went up to bury the slain, he struck down every male in Edom,
verses.comment: Recounts David’s military campaign.

verses.text: for Joab and all Israel stayed there for six months, until he had cut off every male in Edom.
verses.comment: ‘Cut off every male’ is literal from Hebrew, indicating total defeat.

verses.text: But Hadad fled, he and certain Edomite servants of his father with him, to go to Egypt. Hadad was still a little boy.
verses.comment: ‘A little boy’ = ‘na’ar katan’—a young child.

verses.text: They set out from Midian and came to Paran, and they took men from Paran with them and came to Egypt, to Pharaoh king of Egypt, who gave him a house and assigned food to him and gave him land.
verses.comment: Maintains sequence of towns; Pharaoh gave asylum to Hadad.

verses.text: And Hadad found great favor in the sight of Pharaoh, so that he gave him as a wife the sister of his own wife, the sister of Tahpenes the queen.
verses.comment: Retains original relationship terminology.

verses.text: And the sister of Tahpenes bore him a son, Genubath, and Tahpenes weaned him in Pharaoh’s house. Genubath was among the children of Pharaoh.
verses.comment: Weaning is particularly noted in ancient adoption/fostering culture.

verses.text: But when Hadad heard in Egypt that David rested with his fathers and that Joab the commander of the army was dead, Hadad said to Pharaoh, 'Let me depart, that I may go to my own country.'
verses.comment: 'Rested with his fathers' is idiom for 'died.'

verses.text: But Pharaoh said to him, 'What have you lacked with me that, now you seek to go to your own country?' And he said, 'Only let me go.'
verses.comment: A literal exchange; the phrase 'only let me go' retains Hebrew directness.

verses.text: God also raised up another adversary against him, Rezon the son of Eliada, who had fled from his master Hadadezer king of Zobah.
verses.comment: 'Adversary' is again Hebrew 'satan.'

verses.text: And he gathered men to himself and became captain over a raiding band, after the killing by David. And they went to Damascus and lived there and reigned in Damascus.
verses.comment: 'Killing by David' is referring to David’s victory over Hadadezer.

verses.text: He was an adversary to Israel all the days of Solomon, in addition to the trouble caused by Hadad. And he abhorred Israel and reigned over Aram.
verses.comment: 'Aram' preserved for geographic accuracy.

verses.text: Jeroboam the son of Nebat, an Ephraimite of Zeredah, a servant of Solomon whose mother’s name was Zeruah, a widow, also lifted his hand against the king.
verses.comment: 'Lifted his hand' is Hebrew idiom for rebellious action.

verses.text: And this was the reason why he lifted his hand against the king: Solomon built the Millo and closed up the breach of the city of David his father.
verses.comment: 'Built the Millo' has been kept as the Hebrew word since it refers to a specific fortification.

verses.text: Now the man Jeroboam was an able man, and when Solomon saw that the young man was industrious, he appointed him over all the forced labor of the house of Joseph.
verses.comment: 'Forced labor of the house of Joseph' refers to the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh.

verses.text: At that time, when Jeroboam went out of Jerusalem, the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite found him on the road. Now Ahijah had dressed himself in a new cloak, and the two of them were alone in the field.
verses.comment: Details about the new cloak are preserved.

verses.text: And Ahijah took hold of the new cloak that was on him and tore it into twelve pieces.
verses.comment: Literal translation; 'twelve pieces' to symbolize Israel’s tribes.

verses.text: And he said to Jeroboam, 'Take for yourself ten pieces, for thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: “Look, I am about to tear the kingdom out of the hand of Solomon and will give you ten tribes
verses.comment: 'Look' translates Hebrew 'hinneh,' an emphatic particle.

verses.text: but he shall have one tribe, for the sake of my servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem—the city I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel—
verses.comment: 'One tribe' = Judah; phraseology matches Hebrew word order.

verses.text: because they have forsaken me and have worshipped Ashtoreth the goddess of the Sidonians, Chemosh the god of Moab, and Milcom the god of the Ammonites, and have not walked in my ways, to do what is right in my eyes and keep my statutes and my rules, as David his father did.
verses.comment: Each deity named as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: However, I will not take the whole kingdom out of his hand, but I will make him ruler all the days of his life, for the sake of David my servant whom I chose, who kept my commandments and my statutes.
verses.comment: 'Kept my commandments' is the regular term for covenant obedience.

verses.text: But I will take the kingdom out of his son’s hand and will give it to you, ten tribes.
verses.comment: Structure and numerals are according to the MT.

verses.text: Yet to his son I will give one tribe, that David my servant may always have a lamp before me in Jerusalem, the city where I have chosen to put my name.
verses.comment: 'Lamp' is kept as a metaphor for dynasty.

verses.text: And I will take you, and you shall reign over all that your soul desires, and you shall be king over Israel.
verses.comment: 'All your soul desires' is literal rendering.

verses.text: And if you will listen to all that I command you, and walk in my ways, and do what is right in my eyes, keeping my statutes and my commandments, as David my servant did, then I will be with you and will build you a sure house as I built for David, and I will give Israel to you.
verses.comment: 'A sure house' is an idiom for a stable dynasty.

verses.text: I will afflict the offspring of David because of this, but not forever.'
verses.comment: Literal rendering of 'but not forever.'

verses.text: Solomon therefore sought to put Jeroboam to death. But Jeroboam arose and fled into Egypt, to Shishak king of Egypt, and was in Egypt until the death of Solomon.
verses.comment: 'Sought to put Jeroboam to death' is preserved per Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Solomon, and all that he did, and his wisdom, are they not written in the book of the acts of Solomon?
verses.comment: 'Book of the acts of Solomon' is a lost chronicle.

verses.text: Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel forty years.
verses.comment: Time span as in Hebrew.

verses.text: And Solomon slept with his fathers and was buried in the city of David his father. And Rehoboam his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: 'Slept with his fathers' is preserved as a Hebrew euphemism for death.
